sen.e: Yuzuki no kimi (date of birth and death unknown) is a settler who is described as the ancestor of the Hata clan in "Nihonshoki", Chronicles of Japan.

sen.j: 『日本書紀』では応神天皇16年に朝鮮半島の百済から百二十県の人を率いて帰化したという。
sen.e: In "Nihonshoki"(Chronicles of Japan) he naturalized in Japan from Kudara (Paekche) in the 16th year of the reign of the Emperor Ojin with people from 120 counties.

According to "Nihonshoki," he came from Kudara (Paekche), a kingdom on the Korean Peninsula, leading people of 120 counties, and they became naturalized Japanese citizens in 285, the 16th year of the reign of Emperor Ojin.

sen.j: 秦の皇帝（始皇帝とされる）五世の孫であり、渡来後、日本に養蚕・機織を伝えたとされる。
sen.e: He is said to be the descendant in the fifth generation of the first Qin Emperor and have passed on sericulture and weaving to Japan after his arrival.
It is said that he was a grandson of the fifth generation of the Qin Dynasty (and descendant of Shi Huangdi) and that he introduced sericulture and weaving to Japan after his arrival.

sen.j: 加羅（伽耶）または新羅から来たのではないかとも考えられている（新羅は古く辰韓＝秦韓と呼ばれ秦の遺民が住み着いたとの伝承がある）。
sen.e: It is also said that he might be from Gaya or Shilla. (Silla is called Jin Han = Qin Han ("Qin" is pronounced "Hata" in Japanese), and tradition says that the people left from Qin lived there.)

sen.j: また一説には五胡十六国時代に氐族の苻氏が建てた前秦の王族ないし貴族が戦乱の中、朝鮮半島経由で日本にたどり着いたと言う説もある。
sen.e: Another theory holds that the royal family or the nobles of the Former Qin Dynasity built by the Fu clan during the Period of Sixteen Kingdoms reached Japan through the Korean Peninsula during wars.

sen.j: この説に基づくと弓月君が秦の（初代の）皇帝から五世の孫とする記述に反せず、「秦」つながりで渡来した人々が勝手に｢秦｣を名乗り始めたと考えてもさほど矛盾はないが、根拠は少なく今後検証の必要がある。
sen.e: According to this theory, it matches with the description that states Yuzuki no kimi is the descendent of the first Qin Emperor in the fifth generation and there is not much contradiction to consider that the people who came to Japan and related with "Qin" started to call themselves "Hata" on their own, however the evidence is few and it needs to be verified in future.

Although this theory does not contradict the description stating that Yuzuki no kimi was a grandson of the fifth generation from the first Qin Emperor and there is not much contradiction in assuming that people in connection with "Qin" came to Japan and started to call themselves by the surname "Hata" (the kanji character representing "Qin" is pronounced "Hata" in Japanese) on their own, the theory does not have sufficient basis and verification will be required.
